title: Gareth Bale scores on return as Real Madrid see off Espanyol | Football | The Guardian
text:
La Liga Gareth Bale scores on return as Real Madrid see off Espanyol Gareth Bale scores Real Madrid’s second goal past Hernán Pérez in the 2-0 home win that takes his side four points clear at the top of La Liga. Photograph: Angel Martinez/Real Madrid via Getty Images View more sharing options Saturday 18 February 2017 17.43 GMT Last modified on Saturday 18 February 2017 17.44 GMT 
Gareth Bale marked his return from a three-month injury lay-off with a well-taken finish to seal Real Madrid’s 2-0 win over Espanyol at the Bernabéu. 
The Wales forward last played in a Champions League group match at Sporting Lisbon on 22 November before suffering tendon damage in his ankle, which needed surgery. 
The 27-year-old showed he had lost none of his electric pace nor his eye for a cool finish when racing on to a pass from Isco down the left and finding the far corner with eight minutes left. 
A first-half header from Álvaro Morata had set Real Madrid on course for victory, which took them four points clear of Barcelona, who will have played two matches more after they host Leganés on Sunday. 
Zinedine Zidane made the expected sweeping changes from the team that beat Napoli in their midweek Champions League last 16 first-leg tie. 
Luka Modric and Karim Benzema were among those rested completely, while Marcelo and Casemiro were named among the substitutes along with Bale, who has been out for almost three months with a serious ankle injury. 
Pepe came into the centre of defence to partner Raphaël Varane while Lucas Vázquez and Morata led the attack alongside Cristiano Ronaldo. 
After Pepe had sent a header off target, Morata weaved into the left side of the Espanyol penalty area and went to cut the ball back across the six-yard box, but the defender Diego Reyes was alert to made a sliding block. 
There was an enforced stoppage after 24 minutes when Mateo Kovacic needed treatment for a nasty cut under his eye following an accidental clash with Espanyol midfielder Papakouli Diop as the pair jumped for a high ball. The Croat was soon patched up and able to continue. 
Toni Kroos whipped a deep free-kick into the Espanyol area and Morata clipped it over the crossbar, but the offside flag had already gone up. 
On the half-hour, Ronaldo was put clear into the right side of the area but his low shot across the face of goal was touched behind with Morata ready for a tap-in at the far post. 
From the resulting corner, Ronaldo thought he had put Real Madrid in front but his finish at the near post was ruled out for offiside. 
Real Madrid’s pressure eventually told as they took the lead in the 33rd minute. Isco was given time on the right to look up and send over a looping cross, which Morata dispatched into the bottom corner with a flying header. 
Espanyol remained under pressure as the first half drew to a close, with Morata blocked by David López as the striker looked set to slot in a second. 
On 55 minutes, Ronaldo shaped up for a free-kick in a central position 25 yards out, but could only hit his effort into the wall. 
Espanyol thought Hernán Pérez was through on goal after getting the better of Varane on the edge of the Real Madrid penalty area, but the referee called the substitute back for a handball in the tussle, which looked somewhat harsh. 
With 20 minutes left, Bale replaced Morata, to make his return after 88 days on the sidelines. 
Bale gave the home fans just what they wanted after being released by Isco into the left channel, where he held off Pérez’s last-ditch challenge before slotting the ball into the far corner past Diego López from a tight angle after 82 minutes. 
In stoppage time, Ronaldo looked to have been bundled down by Aaron Martin as he arrived at the far post, but instead the officials called up incorrectly for a offside.
